title: Acute Myelopathy Evaluation
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)
G37.3 (Acute transverse myelitis in demyelinating disease)
scope: ** Acute or subacute spinal cord dysfunction — broad differential approach. Covers urgent MRI, LP, and comprehensive workup to differentiate compressive (epidural abscess, tumor, disc herniation, hematoma) from non-compressive causes (inflammatory/demyelinating, vascular, infectious). Compressive myelopathy is a surgical emergency. Excludes chronic cervical spondylotic myelopathy, cauda equina syndrome (separate template), and isolated radiculopathy.

Markedly elevated in epidural abscess (>20 in ~95%); elevated in inflammatory/autoimmune

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine (cervical, thoracic, lumbar) with and without gadolinium contrast (CPT 72156+72157+72158)
Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATELY — within 4 hours of presentation maximum; faster if progressive deficit. Entire spine because multifocal lesions change differential (NMOSD, metastatic)
Essential/First-line.target: Compressive: epidural mass (abscess, tumor, hematoma), disc herniation. Non-compressive: cord signal change (T2 hyperintensity), enhancement pattern, longitudinal extent, location within cord cross-section
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (give contrast anyway if emergent); gadolinium allergy (premedicate); pacemaker

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.target: MS (periventricular/juxtacortical lesions), NMOSD (area postrema, hypothalamic), ADEM (multifocal white matter), metastatic disease, leptomeningeal enhancement

Essential/First-line.timing: ONLY if MRI unavailable or contraindicated; far less sensitive for cord pathology
Essential/First-line.target: Fracture, bony compression, large epidural mass, disc herniation

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; lung malignancy screening (metastatic cord compression); sarcoidosis (hilar adenopathy)

Extended.timing: If metastatic cord compression or sarcoidosis suspected
If spinal cord infarction suspected (especially post-aortic surgery)
Extended.target: Aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm, occlusion of artery of Adamkiewicz

Extended.timing: Spinal dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF); spinal AVM
Extended.target: Abnormal vascular flow voids; fistula identification

Extended.timing: Gold standard for spinal dAVF/AVM; if MRA suggestive
Extended.target: Fistula or AVM identification and localization for treatment

Extended.timing: At 2-4 weeks for treatment response; earlier if clinical worsening
If concomitant peripheral neuropathy suspected (e.g., GBS mimicking myelopathy)
Extended.target: Peripheral nerve involvement vs pure cord

Rare/Specialized.timing: Extremely rare; only for diagnostic uncertainty when all other testing inconclusive and progressive decline

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric treatment of suspected inflammatory myelitis with non-compressive cord lesion

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV methylprednisolone (empiric — inflammatory myelitis) (CPT 96365) 1000 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days (infuse over 1-2h). Start empirically if inflammatory myelitis suspected (non-compressive cord lesion on MRI). Do NOT wait for antibody results
dosing.orderSentence: IV methylprednisolone (empiric — inflammatory myelitis) (CPT 96365) 1000 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection (relative — treat infection concurrently if needed); uncontrolled diabetes

Acute/Emergent.indication: Compressive myelopathy from abscess, tumor, disc herniation, or hematoma

dosing.instructions: For compressive myelopathy: epidural abscess, tumor with cord compression, acute disc herniation with myelopathy, epidural hematoma. Earlier decompression = better neurologic outcome. Within 24h is critical; within 12h is ideal

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Post-op neurologic exam; wound care; DVT prophylaxis

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if: new weakness, worsening numbness, loss of bowel/bladder function, inability to walk, difficulty breathing
Spinal cord injury can improve with treatment — recovery varies by cause (inflammatory often recovers well; vascular and compressive recovery depends on timing)
Bladder management is critical: perform intermittent catheterization as instructed; report urinary retention or incontinence
Bowel program compliance: maintain regular schedule; adequate fiber and fluids
Skin checks daily: pressure injury prevention (reposition every 2h if immobile; use pressure-relieving mattress)
Physical therapy exercises between sessions as instructed
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology
Follow-up with neurology in 1-2 weeks; repeat MRI at 2-4 weeks

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Pressure injury prevention (positioning, specialized mattress, skin checks)
DVT prevention (compression stockings long-term; anticoagulation per protocol)
Autonomic dysreflexia awareness (if thoracic/cervical injury: sudden hypertension, headache, flushing above level — emergency)
Bladder health (adequate fluid intake; catheterization technique; UTI prevention)
Mental health support (spinal cord injury carries high depression/anxiety rates)
Vaccination (if starting immunosuppression: complete vaccines before rituximab/eculizumab)

differential.features: Back pain + fever + neurologic deficit (triad in 10-15%); IVDU, diabetes, spinal procedure risk factors; ESR/CRP very elevated
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (ring-enhancing epidural collection); blood cultures; ESR >20

differential.features: Known malignancy; progressive back pain (often worse at night); bony destruction
differential.tests: MRI (enhancing epidural mass with bony changes); CT body for primary; PET-CT

differential.features: Sudden onset; radiculopathy predominant initially; may progress to myelopathy

differential.tests: MRI (epidural collection; T1 signal depends on age of blood); coagulation panel

differential.features: Non-compressive; T2 cord signal change; may be partial or complete; often thoracic
differential.tests: MRI (T2 hyperintensity <3 segments); LP (pleocytosis); diagnose after excluding MS, NMOSD, MOGAD

differential.features: Partial myelitis (<3 segments); brain lesions present; prior episodes; young adult
differential.tests: MRI brain (periventricular/juxtacortical lesions); oligoclonal bands; short segment cord lesion

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM ≥3 segments); severe; often central cord/gray matter
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG antibody; MRI (LETM, central cord pattern); brain MRI (area postrema lesion)

differential.features: LETM possible; conus/lower cord predilection; may have bilateral optic neuritis
differential.tests: MOG-IgG antibody; MRI pattern; generally better recovery than NMOSD

differential.features: Hyperacute onset (minutes); anterior spinal artery syndrome (motor + pain/temperature loss, preserved proprioception/vibration); often thoracolumbar
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion, "owl eye" or pencil-like on axial); CTA aorta; vascular risk factors

differential.features: Older male; progressive myelopathy with flow voids on MRI; dorsal cord; edema disproportionate to enhancement
differential.tests: MRI (flow voids, dorsal cord edema, enhancement); spinal angiography (gold standard)

differential.features: Ascending weakness; areflexia; may mimic acute myelopathy if rapidly progressive; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; LP (elevated protein, normal cells); no cord signal on MRI

differential.features: Dorsal subpial enhancement; trident sign; may have pulmonary sarcoidosis
differential.tests: Chest CT; ACE level; biopsy; characteristic MRI pattern

differential.features: Endemic area; systemic TB; vertebral body destruction with epidural abscess; gibbus deformity
differential.tests: MRI; AFB culture; TB PCR; QuantiFERON; chest X-ray

differential.diagnosis: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder — See NMOSD above

differential.features: Posterior column dysfunction (proprioception, vibration loss); lightning pains; Argyll Robertson pupils
Posterior column + corticospinal tract (mimics B12 deficiency); gastric surgery, zinc excess
differential.tests: Serum copper and ceruloplasmin; zinc level

differential.features: History of radiation; months to years after treatment; progressive; no enhancement (chronic)
differential.tests: Radiation history; MRI (cord atrophy, signal change within radiation field)

differential.features: Non-anatomic sensory loss; Hoover sign; give-way weakness; normal MRI
differential.tests: Normal MRI; normal LP; clinical exam findings

evidence.recommendation: IV methylprednisolone 1g/day x 3-5 days for inflammatory myelitis

evidence.recommendation: Surgical decompression within 24h for compressive myelopathy

evidence.recommendation: B12 replacement for subacute combined degeneration
